TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit DesignerRegion extends System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerObject

Docs.summary: Defines a region of content within the design-time markup for the associated control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> object represents a region of content within the design-time markup that is generated by a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> implementation. A control developer uses designer regions in a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> implementation to define separate areas within the design-time markup for the associated control and to provide editing and event handling for the area. A visual designer, such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)], can use designer regions to display the separate areas of a control on the design surface and to raise user events for the region to the control designer. Designer regions can simplify a control designer implementation because many region-based features are provided by the base designer classes and the visual designer.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> class provides the base functionality for designer regions, such as the ability to click, select, and highlight a region in the design surface. Use a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> object in a control designer implementation to define a region that does not require editing. Use the derived <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion> class in a control designer implementation to define a region with editable content at design time. Use the derived <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedEditableDesignerRegion> class in a control designer implementation to define an editable region that represents a template in a control.
To support regions within a class that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner>, override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method and add one or more initialized <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> objects to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegionCollection> collection. Optionally, you can handle mouse clicks in the regions on the design surface by overriding the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method.
Use the properties of a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> object to determine how the region is displayed by the visual designer. Override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Selectable%2A> property to indicate that the region can be selected by the user on the design surface. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Highlight%2A> property to highlight the designer region in the visual designer; for example, you can highlight a region after a user has clicked to select it. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.DisplayName%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Description%2A> properties to store or retrieve additional details about the region. In particular, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Description%2A> property is used by the visual designer to display ToolTip information when the user moves the mouse pointer over the designer region. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerObject.Designer%2A> property to access the methods and properties of the control designer object that contains the designer region.

Docs.related: Extending Design-Time Support
How to: Extend the Appearance and Behavior of Controls in Design Mode

## Remarks The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> class.
|Property|Initial Value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Description%2A>|An empty string ("").| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerObject.Designer%2A>|The input `designer` object.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.DisplayName%2A>|An empty string ("").| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.EnsureSize%2A>|`false`.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Highlight%2A>|`false`.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerObject.Name%2A>|The input `name` object.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerObject.Properties%2A>|An empty <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.HybridDictionary> object.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Selectable%2A>|`false`.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.Selected%2A>|`false`.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.UserData%2A>|`null`.|

Docs.summary: Defines the HTML attribute name for a designer region.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The attribute name for a designer region is `_designerRegion`. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.DesignerRegionAttributeName> field is used to identify regions within the design-time HTML markup for the control designer.

Docs.related: Extending Design-Time Support
How to: Extend the Appearance and Behavior of Controls in Design Mode

Docs.value: An object that contains user data stored for the designer region. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Within a control designer implementation, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.UserData%2A> property to store or retrieve additional information for the designer region.
For example, if the control designer implementation supports selecting from multiple designer regions, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.UserData%2A> property in a control designer to store a unique index for each region. You can then use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion.UserData%2A> property for the region that is passed into the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method to store the index for the currently selected region.

Docs.related: Extending Design-Time Support
How to: Extend the Appearance and Behavior of Controls in Design Mode
